Pierre Joseph Thuot (pronounced THOO-it) is a retired United States Navy Captain and NASA astronaut.
He went into space three times, spending over 650 hours in space, including over 15 hours in three space walks.
He is a former U.S. record holder for time spent on one space walk, and participated in the first three-person space walk.
Born on May 19, 1955, in Groton, Connecticut, Thuot considers Fairfax, Virginia and New Bedford, Massachusetts to be his hometowns.
He is married to the former Cheryl Ann Mattingly of Leonardtown, Maryland, and they have two children.
Thuot enjoys boating, golf, running, music, flying and family activities.
Thuot graduated from Fairfax High School, Fairfax, Virginia, in 1973.
He also graduated from the Harvard Business School Advanced Management Program in 2004.
He held the U.S. and absolute world records for total time spent on space walks: 8 hours and 29 minutes from 1992 until 2001.
Thuot graduated 30th in his class from the U.S. Naval Academy in 1977 and commenced Naval Flight Officer training in July 1977.
He was then assigned to Fighter Squadron 14 (VF-14) and deployed to the Mediterranean and Caribbean Seas aboard the USSJohn F. Kennedy and USSIndependence.
While assigned to VF-14, he attended the Navy Fighter Weapons School (TOPGUN).
He was then selected to attend the U.S. Naval Test Pilot School in May 1982.
He has over 3,500 flight hours in more than 50 different aircraft, and has over 270 carrier landings.
Selected as an astronaut by NASA in June 1985, Thuot has served in a variety of technical assignments.
He served as the lead astronaut for Space Station integrated assembly and maintenance operations within the Astronaut Office.
He served as Chief of the Astronaut Office Mission Support Branch, as well as supervising Astronaut Candidate training for the class of 1995.
